fasting: Pregnant women, nursing mothers, the ill, and those in significant pain should consult a rabbi regarding the fast.
Children below bar/bat-mitzvah age may not fast, and they need not be accustomed to fasting even for a few hours.
The fast ends with the appearance of the stars.
Since one may not eat before the Megilla reading, the fast effectively continues until after the reading is completed.
prayers: During the repetition of the Amida, the chazzan recites 'Aneinu' between 'Go'el Yisrael' and 'Refa'enu'.
Selichot are recited even if a chatan or a brit milah is present (though those individuals do not recite Selichot).
The Torah portion 'Vayechal' is read only if at least three people in the minyan are fasting.
If fewer than three are fasting, the weekly portion 'Ki Tisa' is read instead.
At Mincha, those fasting recite 'Aneinu' in the blessing 'Shome'a Tefilla'.
Tachnun and 'Avinu Malkeinu' are not recited at Mincha.
machatzit_hashekel: Before Mincha it is customary to give tzedaka in memory of the half-shekel.
One should give three coins each worth half of the local currency (e.g., three half-dollar coins in the USA).
It is customary to give on behalf of each family member, and children should be encouraged to give from their own money.

megilla_reading: Every Jewish man and woman is obligated to hear the entire Megilla â€” once at night and once during the day.
Every single word must be heard; if even one word is missed, the obligation is not fulfilled.
The Megilla may not be heard via loudspeaker, telephone, or radio.
One may not speak from the beginning of the blessings until the end of the blessing 'Ha-Rav et Rivenu'.
Before the reading, the Megilla is unrolled and folded into three parts like a letter.
The reader stands during the reading out of respect for the congregation.
Noise (groggers) is made only when Haman's name is mentioned together with his title.
The ten sons of Haman and the word 'aseret' must be read in a single breath.
The congregation also recites the names of the ten sons of Haman in a single breath before the reader does.
mishloach_manot: One is obligated to send at least two portions of ready-to-eat food or drink to one person.
Men send to men; women send to women.
It is preferable to send through a messenger, ideally a child.
The minimum amount for each portion is a ke-zayit (approximately 27 cubic centimeters).
matanot_la_evyonim: One is obligated to give at least one gift each to two poor people.
A poor person is one who lacks sufficient funds for their family's basic needs.
It is permitted to give from a man to a woman and vice versa.
The minimum amount is a pruta (about 30 agorot), but it is preferable to give the value of a meal.
It is better to increase spending on gifts to the poor than on the festive meal or mishloach manot.
The money must reach the poor on Purim itself.
purim_feast_and_rejoicing: One is obligated to hold a festive meal with meat (preferably beef) and bread.
It is obligatory to drink wine or other alcoholic beverages until one cannot distinguish between 'Cursed is Haman' and 'Blessed is Mordechai'.
Chabad restriction: men under 40 should not drink more than one reviit (approximately 86 ml) of wine.
Women are obligated in all the Purim mitzvot except the obligation to become intoxicated.
It is customary to eat hamantaschen, kreplach (with meat), and grain dishes.
work: Heavy labor such as building or sewing is not strictly forbidden but is customarily avoided.
Household tasks and work done for the purpose of the holiday are permitted.

halachot.general: In cities without ancient walls, Tachnun and 'Al Ha-Nissim' are not recited.
halachot.jerusalem: In Jerusalem, Purim is celebrated today with all its mitzvot.
doubtful_cities: All Purim mitzvot are observed; 'Al Ha-Nissim' is recited and the Torah is read.
The Megilla is read after prayers without a blessing.
Heavy labor should be avoided on this day.

special_instructions_for_mivtzoim.megilla: If listeners cannot concentrate on every word, the blessing should not be recited.
special_instructions_for_mivtzoim.mishloach_manot: If no prepared sets are available, portions of food may be exchanged in a hospital or army setting.
special_instructions_for_mivtzoim.matanot_la_evyonim: It is recommended to carry a tzedaka box to immediately pass money to the poor.
special_instructions_for_mivtzoim.feast: Those going out on mivtzoim must eat at least a ke-beitza of bread after Mincha but before sunset.
